@Bitcoinfinity @ShapeShift @Arkeonetwork Nope

No VCs own it
No corporate entities control it

The revolution will not be centralized. Enjoy!

Services that consume node data pay for that data (@infura_io is great... but they can censor you: they're centralized).

With Arkeo, all such services now have a permissionless alternative.
Arkeo works by incentivizing independent node operators to run arbitrary nodes on whatever chains they wish. Someone could run a Bitcoin node only, or a suite of nodes across multiple chains.

ShapeShift decided to build this because it ran into this very problem: how can we be a *truly* decentralized app when we're calling blockchain data from centralized node companies? 

If your node provider can shut off your access, it ain't permissionless. Arkeo is.

üßµ Behind the scenes, @ShapeShift DAO has been building something called Arkeo.

It's a decentralized backend for nodes.

If you've ever thought, "sucks that everyone uses centralized node infrastructure like Infura..." then you'll understand what Arkeo is solving.

9) "Decentralizing money through something like Bitcoin simply makes Bitcoin oligarchs. "

9a No it doesn't. Rich people's sins include enjoying leisure and offering you a job. They can't steal your money, which is what the State does with every debased dollar it prints.

8a  This is an unexamined position. To claim national governments and corporations are somehow equivalent in the wielding of power... I'll believe this when Google murders people with drones and Bezos imprisons me for smoking a plant.

8) "I dislike the state because I dislike any concentration of power which is unaccountable and unanswerable to the people. 

But equally, equally, I despise the central authority of Google, of Facebook, of private sources of concentrated power. "

7) "The idea that you can keep the state, and simply democratize money through decentralization is just bonkers."

7a He's onto something finally... üòè

6b It doesn't matter who controls the money printer. The act of legally compelling a populace to trade with fiat while debasing that fiat is itself theft. A different thief with different justifications doesn't make currency debasement magically ethical.

6) "My criticism with [central banks] is not that they have the power to expand and contract the supply of money, but the way they use it. "

6a This is the old "if only our guys were in power, things would be better... if only WE could manipulate money instead of THEM"

5a2 Reality: the US was built on apolitical money (gold), and this was the standard until 1971. 

Sure, you can blame Great Depression on gold if you also give credit to gold for the entire industrial revolution and the rise of America from agrarian backwater to world power.

5) "The one time we had historical records when we had a fixed supply of money, an apolitical money, was 1929. "

5a This is deceptive... as though there was some tiny example in which we "experimented" with an apolitical money and that was 1929 which caused Depression.

4) "Imagine how much worse [COVID] would have been if we had money that could not be expanded rapidly as a result of a political decision." 

4a Pristine example of Bastiat's "unseen." The unseen cost here is the years of price inflation now decimating the people. Yanis ignores.

3) "We need authorities that have the capacity to expand/contract the money supply, in response to economic upturns and downturns. "

3a The existence of this power is relatively recent and during its time we've seen wealth disparity and global debt skyrocket. Do we *need* that?

2) "The main reason [capitalism requires fiat] is that the quantity of money has to be adjustable"

2a Again, the entire 19th century (arguably capitalism's greatest century) occurred without an adjustable money supply.

1a2
Fiat money is a parasite currently living within an otherwise healthy capitalist host. Can crypto replace fiat? We shall see, but if it does, capitalism will rejoice.

It's absurd to claim a market-based economy should have a centrally-planned money.

1a Yanis begins upon a foundation of sophistry. 

He claims capitalism requires fiat: demonstrably false  considering modern fiat money only began in 1971 (prior it was gold). I believe capitalism existed (indeed thrived) for at least 250 years in US prior to 1971.

Again, I have nearly nothing to do with the leadership and management of ShapeShift any longer. 

ShapeShift has decentralized, and demonstrated that decentralization is properly just a means to an end: the production of beautiful, principled product.

We've been crucified by the community for decisions which we were sometimes *legally prohibited from even explaining.*

But the ShapeShift team has adapted to every obstacle in pursuit of principle. 

And seeing this mobile app live today, brings a smile to my face.

ShapeShift has been fighting for the principles that make crypto important since 2014. 

For this, we've been harassed by a litany of government agencies hell-bent on controlling and surveilling how allegedly free peoples interact economically.

Crucially, it's multi-chain. This is not just another ETH-based wallet. It supports:

- native Bitcoin 
- @cosmos 
- @avalancheavax 

It's architecture enables further chains to be added. 

There is no KYC. It is borderless. The front-end is redundant over IPFS.

The new mobile app release is a special milestone, because this app was developed entirely by the DAO. 

No funding came from any investors. There is no CEO, and there are no formal employees. There is structure and hierarchy, but it is not corporate.

And the app is beautiful!

There are very few crypto companies that have achieved this set.  

For example, Metamask is not community owned. Coinbase is not Private nor Open source. FTX is custodial.

We became a DAO in order to be able to pursue these virtues. Centralized companies arguably cannot do so.

The ShapeShift app is best described as a crypto interface. It's compatible with multiple wallets (Metamask, WalletConnect, native Bitcoin wallet, etc)

There are several bullet points on the splash screen...

- 100% free
- Open Source
- Community Owned
- Non-Custodial
- Private

I'd acknowledge that Gresham's Law is colloquially used by many people to refer to @nvk's definition. 

But in terms of precise definitional accuracy, who is right?

w/o a fixed exchange rate, G's Law is not applicable, because assets change in price based on supply and demand. There is no need/mechanism where one asset becomes scarce. 

The scarcity of the "Good money" occurs only when and specifically because of price imbalance due 2 peg.

My understanding is that it's an observation of what happens when someone (ie a State) artificially fixes exchange rate between two separate assets/commodities. Historically, this was a fixed rate between gold & silver or coins w/ different precious metal content.

Poll:
At the Roundtable a couple months ago, I got into very heated debate with @nvk about Gresham's Law. 

His definition: Bad money drives out good *generally.*

My definition: Bad money drives out good *specifically under the condition of a fixed exchange rate.*
@CACryptoNerd @TheRuneRanger It's earned as a proportional share of the pool, so 50/50 UST/RUNE.

@StackingMonero @TheRuneRanger It's not rewards or subsidy.

It's a measure of trade fees (0.3%) divided by liquidity. 

Higher trade volumes means more fees. High volume and relatively low liquidity means higher yield. Low volume with high liquidity would mean lower yield. 

Self-correcting/balanced.

@THORChain Stated differently, IBC *will be* integrated with Thorchain, but only with Thorchain's synths (which are cosmos/tendermint assets), not with relatively incompatible L1 assets in the liquidity pools.

TLDR of this...

IBC is built for cosmos/tendermint chains. 

Thorchain liquidity pools are native L1 chains that are *not* cosmos/tendermint. 

Applying IBC to those assets is highly complex and fraught with security problems. 

Better to use IBC solely with synths on @thorchain

It's the exercise of the decentralization principle. Many small entities, each with different relevant actions, jurisdictions, resources, rather than one target with deep pockets to go after. 

And each individual can do or not do this at their discretion.

To solve: any individual participating in a DAO, who is concerned with liability, can create their own LLC through which they interact with the DAO.

Then, if liability for a specific action exists, it is first defended at entity level with the explicit limitations therein.

There is a theory that DAO's suffer from the lack of "limited liability" that a corporate entity provides. Those who contribute to the #DAO are vulnerable as individuals with no corporate shield. 

It seems this can be solved fairly easily.

Two points on this...

1) A defi protocol cannot comply with regulations, US or otherwise. If a protocol can comply, it is not defi, but cefi.

Further, if A isn't true, then is it really moral to force ineffective vaccines? 

And if B isn't true, then mandates are immoral because not everyone who wants to get it is even able to (you're forcing Bob to take it instead of Alice who voluntarily wanted to)

If the vaccine is A) highly effective and B) widely available, then there can be no moral argument to justify forced vaccines. 

Why?

Because those who want to be protected can be, & those who prefer no vaccine can't be said to substantially endanger the former (because of A+B)

After this transformation, there is no corp. No CEO. No board. No shareholders. No employees. No banks. No office. No statist OSHA posters. 

What remains is pure technology in the service of  users: an open-source, non-custodial, cross-chain crypto interface for all mankind.

We now continue transforming ShapeShift from a central entity into a decentralized autonomous organization, governed marginally at first, and then completely, by FOX holders.

A DAO treasury of roughly 1/4 of the FOX supply has been placed in the hands of these holders.

We have granted tokens to our beloved employees, our supportive investors, and as of this morning, over one million ShapeShift customers and defi community members. In terms of recipients this was the largest airdrop in history. 

Many projects have been inspirational to us‚Ä¶

We‚Äôre stepping into that future, & away from the trappings of equity and incorporation.

Equity and incorporation fasten an organization to jurisdictional friction. 

Appropriate for industrial companies in the 20th century. 

Inappropriate for digital companies in the 21st.

Tokens, more than equity ever can be, are borderless and immutable. To build a global platform for crypto finance, this is the appropriate base of economic arrangement. 

Tokens have been abused, but they are the future.

Starting today, we begin open-sourcing the ShapeShift project, dissolving our corporate structure toward zero, and re-organizing around a borderless, decentralized community governed by the holders of the FOX token.

Upon much reflection, we‚Äôve come to the conclusion that the vision of an immutable, borderless financial system can only occur upon open, decentralized protocols.

So we‚Äôll start with ourselves. We must be the change we wish to see in the world.

Money shall emerge from markets, and this is what crypto has always been about. 

It‚Äôs a destiny unlocked by the invention of #Bitcoin, & by the blooming ecosystem of assets and crypto-economics that #Ethereum unleashed. 

We love these systems & must build with fidelity to them.

But why should we, an established and well-funded for-profit corporation, consider such a model?

Simple: centralization has become a liability against the realization of our vision.

DAO‚Äôs are emerging from their trough of disillusionment.  They are dynamic, they are non-jurisdictional, and they are shockingly powerful.  

They have no center. They rely on no bank account. 

They demonstrate anti-fragile, emergent order.

But if you‚Äôre familiar with the Fourth Turning paradigm, you may understand that the organizational format that succeeded during the Industrial Age may not be the optimal format for the digital age.  

There is a new kind of ‚Äúfirm.‚Äù The decentralized autonomous organization #DAO

This corporate model is standard for all economic organization at scale, persisting through the 20th century and into the 21st.  

Every company is structured roughly in this way, with a plan to IPO, acquire, or be acquired.

We have investors, a board, an exec team, corporate entities, bank accounts, an HR department, a beautiful office overlooking the mountains to the west, paid ‚Äúour taxes,‚Äù and like proper conformists we even followed all OSHA workplace signage requirements in our break room.

ShapeShift has been a centralized company for 7 years. 

We pioneered the self-custody revolution, enabling people to trade assets without counter-party risk.

It has always been our goal to protect users, while making self-custody easy and fun.

Today, we announced that ShapeShift is decentralizing.

Unorthodox, but it is the only way to maintain fidelity to the most important principles of crypto; specifically, self-sovereignty over money.
 
Without that principle upheld, we‚Äôre all just LARP‚Äôing.

To illustrate:

I'm a merchant in the US and I don't want to accept dirty USD fiat garbage. I'll only accept Bitcoin.   This is LEGAL. I am not required to accept USD.

But if someone owes me a debt, for whatever past exchange, and he offers me USD to settle, I must accept.

There seems to be some confusion on what "legal tender" means. 

It *does not* mean someone must receive payment in a specific form. 

It *does* mean someone must accept that form of payment to settle a debt, if the debtor prefers to pay in said form. 

Important difference.

20/ Anything that causes normal people to consider new forms of money (apart from their default position of "my nation, my currency") is a good thing. Libra will crack open further global discussion about what money is, and that sunshine will hurt fiat, and help all sound monies.

19/ Ultimately, Libra‚Äôs relationship with those of us in crypto will be mixed. It will be a love/hate relationship, and that‚Äôs okay. Libra is challenging the status quo of fiat more than it challenges true crypto, and will pull millions toward sound-er money long term.

18/ Libra has a chance, if they are brave and tactical over many years, to ultimately move away from a fiat basket toward either a real basket (BTC, gold, etc), or possibly just becoming a hard asset on its own (requiring knowable supply with zero or low debasement).

17/ Libra may also become the whipping boy of cryptocurrency. As the politicians of the world get irate at having their fiat supremacy challenged, they will call on FB to answer for it. These struggles, playing out over the coming years, will be fascinating.

16/ Libra, because it is *kinda* a cryptocurrency will *kinda* run up against many of the legal/regulatory challenges that real cryptos and crypto companies do. FB has the resources (and hopefully the balls) to fight some of the battles.

15/ Over the short/medium term, this relative stability derived by fiat/bond backing will enable Libra to capture marketshare and onboard literally hundreds of millions of people. They will be moving partially away from banks, and partially toward true decentralized finance.

14/ Over the long term, any currency based on fiat will fail relative to hard assets (Bitcoin, gold, etc.) Politicians debase currency as their modus operandi, and thus if Libra maintains fiat backing it tend toward zero long term. BTC and ‚Äúreal‚Äù cryptos will crush it long term.

13/ Next: Libra achieves stability (a critical feature for most normies) by backing the coin with a basket of a) government fiat, and b) government debt (bonds). Personally, I want nothing to do with either of these ‚Äúassets.‚Äù

12/ Next: the governing consortium can explicitly block/prevent txs. You won‚Äôt find unstoppable finance here. Again, in this, traditional cryptos are far superior. But let‚Äôs be realistic, there‚Äôs no way FB could create an unstoppable coin (at least, not in its 1st phase‚Ä¶)

11/  Now the bad: Libra is clearly not a ‚Äúpure cryptocurrency.‚Äù Nobody should expect privacy by using it. Nobody should expect the true borderless standard of most cryptos. Libra will never be available in Iran due to sanctions, for example.

10/ Finally, and let‚Äôs not minimize this one, Libra has a good chance of helping hundreds of millions of people avoid middlemen fees and increase their wealth and financial sovereignty *relative to the status quo banking system* Humanitarians rejoice.

9/ Next, Libra has the potential (and current plan) to go from ‚Äúa little decentralized‚Äù on day one, to ‚Äúmoderately decentralized‚Äù within a few years of launch. The plan is clearly to gradually decentralize with time. Good plan, we‚Äôll see if they can actually do it.

8/ To whomever bravely navigated Facebook into creating a currency above the US dollar, kudos to you. That took balls and probably a lot of work. It was the right decision. I was worried FB Coin would just be a lame proxy for US dollar, and it is not.

7/ Next, Libra made the (great) decision to NOT back itself solely with USD. This has profound implications. Libra can arguably become a medium-term replacement to any single government fiat currency. Libra is, arguably, superior/above the US Government dollar.

6/ The Good: Libra is built on an actual blockchain (based on HotStuff BFT, similar but not identical to, and compatible with, Cosmos‚Äô Tendermint protocol). Much/most of the important components are open-source and can be built on in a permissionless way.

5/ Libra will serve the mass market, and be the single largest bridge toward decentralized finance that has ever been built. Prior to this, the largest bridge was Coinbase, which has played an integral role in crypto‚Äôs rise.

4/ Lots of blockchain projects will be created and played with while the world rebuilds the financial system upon this new technology. Different assets will serve different markets, at different times, in different ways.

3/ Libra deserves nuanced analysis, it is neither ‚Äúgreat‚Äù nor ‚Äúhorrendous.‚Äù This brings up an important point too often missing in discussions of crypto: digital assets and blockchains have *many* attributes, optimizing for certain ones can detract from others, and that‚Äôs okay.

2/ I know, I know, ‚Äúit‚Äôs not a cryptocurrency!!!‚Äù some will yell.  Well, yes and no. Relative to PayPal or to the US dollar, Libra is very much a cryptocurrency.  Relative to Bitcoin or ZCash or DAI, Libra is not all that crypto-y.
